newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Sept 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Sept 17.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa says in an interview he will not step down from his post and was ready to face a no confidence motion against him to be debated in parliament from Wednesday. He said if he wins the vote he will revamp his economic team to address urgent economic issues (BANGKOK POST)

- Five coalition parties plan to give Banharn an ultimatum tomorrow to resign or face damaging exposures about his nationality, coalition sources said. They will demand that he resign and hand the premiership to Deputy Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh. (BANGKOK POST)
- Government whips resolved to back Banharn in the upcoming no-confidence debate, saying all six parties in the coalition will attend the debate and support the prime minister. (THE NATION)

- Prime Minister Banharn has submitted an annual military reshuffle list to the King for approval. The prime minister denied that he had been delaying the military reshuffle to use it as a bargaining chip with his major coalition partner, New Aspiration Party leader Chavalit. (BANGKOK POST)

- Court in the northeastern province of Buri Ram has ordered the seizure of cash found at the home of election vote-buying suspects. But the court cleared the two suspects of any electoral offence on the grounds that the prosecution failed to prove a crime had actually been committed. (THE NATION)
- Investors think a change in political leadership will lead to a rise in the stock market, an informal survey of local and foreign investors shows (BANGKOK POST)

- Prime Minister Banharn says some groups are dumping shares in an attempt to batter the market and tarnish his government's image. He did not elaborate or say whether legal action would be taken against anyone trying to manipulate the market downward. (BANGKOK POST)
- Nineteen consortia have submitted bids to build and operate power plant joint ventures with the state-run Industrial Estate Authority of Thailand. The bidding was closed on Friday. (THE NATION)
